repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second North West Frontier
            Province (NWFP) Community Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second North West
            Frontier Province (NWFP) Community Infrastructure Project
            for Pakistan were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was high, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: implementing a community based project
            through a local government system that has been recently
            introduced needs sustained commitment at all levels and a
            major emphasis on institutional and behavioral change. As a
            high risk approach, sufficient resources are required to
            support institutional development and high level champions
            are needed to maintain commitment and progress. There is a
            need to review the evolving local government system in the
            province and prepare approaches for rural development
            projects that are community based with effective support
            from government in partnership with civil society
            organizations. Implementing community projects in
            environments that are highly insecure need to have a
            flexible design and use locally trusted organizations. The
            security situation in the province deteriorated rapidly
            since the predecessor project making it difficult for the
            government agency to implement and for the World Bank to
            provide implementation support. The design needs to be
            flexible to allow changes in approach, ways of working and
            expected outcomes. Recovery of the outstanding advance
            should be started at an early stage to avoid problems such
            as the exchange losses. Bank staff should closely monitor
            the available balance in the DA in both currencies i.e. PAK
            and or US Dollars. A rural development project that requires
            field work with staff inputs from local governments needs to
            provide appropriate logistical support. Local governments
            often face budget and mobility issues, and if appropriate
            support in the form of financial support and vehicles is not
            provided by the project, they need to mobilize resources
            from their own alternative sources. Preparation of new
            budget item for local governments to procure a new vehicle
            can require a long period of time and would not easily be
            approved. However, in order to implement effectively a rural
            project that requires frequent field visits, it is important
            to carry out an assessment of staff mobility and constraints
            of local government bodies.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - North West Frontier Province
            On-Farm Water Management Project, and Second North West
            Frontier Province Community Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed additional credit and the
            reallocated amount for Pakistan will help finance the costs
            associated with the new activities that include, (i) repairs
            of breaches in canal embankments, removal of debris
            deposited in the canal prisms and repair of control
            structures, drainage structures and water storage
            infrastructure; (ii) re construction and/r repairs of
            damaged roads, culverts and bridges; (iii) repair and/or
            reconstruction of public buildings such as schools, health
            facilities and buildings; (iv) repair of damaged drinking
            water supply and sanitation systems; and (v) assisting
            households and families to reestablish their livelihood by
            helping in the reconstruction of their houses, restarting
            their agricultural activities by providing agricultural
            technology packages, restocking their livestock devastated
            by the floods and earthquake and providing livelihood
            support to households and individuals affected by the
            disaster. There will be no change to the ongoing project activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit for the North West Frontier Province Project

abstracts.cdata!:
On October 8, 2005, a powerful
            earthquake measuring 7.6 on the Richter scale hit northern
            Pakistan. Pakistan has borne the brunt of the earthquake,
            especially 5 northeastern districts of the North West
            Frontier Province (NWFP) and three districts covering most
            of had Jammu and Kashmir (AJK), with enormous loss of life
            and devastation of infrastructure and property.  The Bank is
            preparing a proposed package of US$ 470 million to help
            Pakistan deal with the reconstruction effort and safeguard
            the on-going reform and poverty reduction program, which
            will include supplemental financing of US$ 150 million under
            the Poverty Reduction Support Program (PRSC 1) and of US$ 50
            million under the Second Structural Adjustment Credit for
            the North West Frontier Province (NWFP SAC 2). This report
            covers the proposed Supplemental Financing of US$ 50
            million, which will support the sustained implementation of
            the NWFP SAC2 reform program, and help finance part of the
            gap in resources incurred as a result of the earthquake. The
            NWFP SAC 2 is the second in a series of three operations to
            support the implementation of the Government of NWFP's
            Provincial Reform Program. The NWFP SAC 2 has been
            supporting implementation of the provincial
            government's reform program, and is based on five
            pillars: (1) Accelerating economic growth and promoting
            private sector development; (2) Accelerating human
            development and improving social service delivery; (3)
            Fiscal reforms; (4) Governance reforms in public financial
            management and procurement; and (5) Reforms to achieve an
            efficient, accountable, and service oriented civil service.
            It is critical that the provincial fiscal framework remains
            sustainable while relief and rehabilitation takes place.
            Supplemental program support will be an important source of
            budget financing for the Government as it will provide
            financing at a time when the impact of the disaster on
            government revenues is unknown; and there is an urgent need
            for additional government expenditure. Supplemental
            financing for NWFP SAC 2 will thus complement the support
            for short term medium-term rehabilitation that will be
            provided through the restructuring and reprogramming of
            ongoing operations in the Bank's portfolio. It will
            also complement the assistance provided by other
            multilateral, in particular the ADB, and bilateral agencies.
            Finally, the Supplemental Financing will contribute to
            minimizing the risks to the overall reform program, maintain
            the integrity of the transition to, and the preparation of,
            the follow up operation-the first NWFP Development Policy Credit.

Pakistan - Second Structural Adjustment

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - North West Frontier Province
            (NWFP) Community Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the context of the Poverty
            Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP), the Second North West
            Frontier Province Community Infrastructure Project (CIP-II),
            builds on the successful experiences of the first CIP, and
            other complementary programs in the NWFP, but adapts it to
            devolution. The project will be open to all participating
            tehsil municipal administration (TMA) units that have
            demonstrated their capacity to manage the program, and
            within these to all communities, taking into account the
            readiness of residents to participate, the level of poverty,
            and current access to basic infrastructure. The main
            objective of the project is to promote the well being of low
            income communities of NWFP by: (a) supporting investments in
            community development activities, basic services, and small
            scale productive infrastructure; and, (b) strengthening
            capacity at the new devolved local government and community
            levels, to plan and deliver such services and
            infrastructure. The project's three main components
            are: 1) local infrastructure and  services, involving
            support to participating Citizen Community boards (CCBs),
            and TMAs sub-project investments in small scale, and
            productive infrastructure projects; 2) improving local level
            performance, through two distinct sub-components:
            institutional strengthening, and community development
            activities; and, 3) implementation support, monitoring and
            evaluation, through a) technical assistance, mostly local
            and regional, for capacity building and training, to improve
            local capacity, particularly at the tehsil level; and, b)
            implementation support to the Local Government Election and
            Rural Development Department (LG&RDD) to improve overall
            administration and coordination, including supervision,
            monitoring and impact evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second NWFP Community
            Infrastructure Project : social assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This social assessment looks at the
            socioeconomic perspective within the Second North West
            Frontier Province - NWFP - Community Infrastructure Project
            (CIPII), and evaluates social and institutional
            organizations, including institutional arrangements under
            devolution, examines gender status, reviews the First CIP
            components, and proposes monitoring and evaluation to be
            pursued, within a consultation framework, based on the
            assessment of social safeguards, and critical risks. The
            consultation process involved a wide participation of
            stakeholders, local communities, existing Citizen's
            Community Boards (CCBs) and nongovernmental organizations
            (NGOs), as well as the private sector, and government
            agencies. This process fostered an approach that involves
            local communities to devise practical solutions, through
            CCBs in a community action planning process, based on human,
            financial, and operation and maintenance commitments, to
            integrate physical, social, and economic components with the
            leadership of the CCB. The role of women should be
            incorporated, and strengthened in all aspects of the
            program. To this end, support will be provided through
            training assistance, and institutional capacity building,
            and in addition, focused groups discussions among the
            community members shall address the needs and requirements
            to improve infrastructure, for appropriate financial
            management, and, to continue a traditional contribution of
            voluntary land donation for public benefit. Water quality,
            waste disposal, overgrazing and deforestation are concerns
            that will be monitored through water conservation practices
            (and water rationing if needed), waste management, and
            community involvement. Moreover, infrastructure development,
            particularly water supply and roads, shall contribute to
            poverty alleviation, by providing income generation
            activities, while improvement of health facilities,
            especially preventive practices, would be cost-saving instruments.
